Movie description on viewing app described this as a "Big Budget" film. Perhaps a "bigger" budget than other films but in comparison to other recent Biblical stories to light up the big screen, this one slightly misses the mark. Particularly, the lines of "Goliath" which are clearly dubbed showed signs of cutting corners in places where they thought people wouldn't notice. The story of David as told in the Bible was written in the movie as in the Bible. Thus not taking anything away from it. The "filler" screenplay writing didn't transition all that well, though. The characters are in one moment of a scene and without any kind of lead, the next scene jumps days, even weeks into the future without warning or cluing the viewer in. Also there were certain anomalies that likely happened in the post-edit. Like thunder crashing when the scene is showing clear, blue skies or the voice dialog fading in and out of volume while in open scenery.

Some positive points are that movie retained the Biblical story in tact. While the acting wasn't an "A-list" performance, some delivered not in dialog but in presentation. Some really captured what it was like to be their character. Especially, unknown Miles Sloman who really seemed to express the level of frustration of David as he was continually passed over as being nothing more than "shepherd boy." Overall, the movie was as good as one would expect from a B-Reel my main disappointment was that the description, the media, and trailer had made this out to be an epic depiction of the classic tale. When in reality, it was simply a mediocre Bible flick.

Did I enjoy it? Yes.
Was it a "big budget" cinematic experience? No.

An excellent video production of a great Bible event found in 1 Samuel chapter 17.  The movie depicts King Saul's lack of confidence in David as a warrior, as well as the struggle between David the shepherd and his brothers.  As the armies draw up in battle array, Goliath is first shown cursing and goading the Israelites, and eventually David too.  Eventually King Saul accepts David's offer to fight the giant.  But David turns down King Saul's offer of armor and a sword.  David remains the humble shepherd.  David states his confidence is in the "living God".  When David's stone strikes Goliath's forehead, the giant falls to the ground with a thud.  Although verse 51 says David then ran to Goliath and cut off his head with the giant's own sword, the movie doesn't show the beheading, just the sword's downward action.  So this visual depiction should not disturb small children.  At first glance the actor cast as David might not fit one's expectation of this Bible hero.  But the Bible says in 1 Samuel chapter 17 verse 42, that David was a "youth".  And that he was "ruddy, with a handsome appearance" (NASB).  So perhaps the movie casting isn't too far off.  The lead actor portraying David certainly gave a believable performance.

The bulk of the movie is simply everyone declaring David can't win, and David declaring that with God's help he can win. It ends up being a long build up to a boring fight.

Goliath isn't the least bit intimidating. He's a tall, out-of-shape guy that likes to yell. Oh, I'm scared:) Any well-trained soldier would tear this guy to shreds. If the antagonist of the movie isn't scary, and the whole climax of the movie is based on a battle with him, there really isn't any tension to drive the plot.

King Saul looks like a weakling. According to Biblical accounts, he was head and shoulders above the rest of the Israelites. An imposing king Saul is necessary to drive the story line, because then everyone wonders why the warrior-king isn't going out to face the giant. Instead, this movie presents Saul as a mushy, gutless figure. In the Biblical account, Saul is a tormented individual who ends up jealous of the young shepherd who kills the giant. The Biblical character is multifaceted. The Saul in the movie is one-dimensional and flaccid.

The final fight scene with Goliath is boring. The two circle each other for what seems like an eternity, before David hits him in the head with a rock and then cuts off his head. In the Biblical account, after the beheading, the Israelites chase the Philistines and a humiliating defeat ensues. But, this movie doesn't include the exciting battle. Why not?

There is a subplot of a love story between David and Saul's daughter, Michal. But, this subplot is devoid of any chemistry.

The strong point of the movie (if there was any) was the acting of the young man who played David. While none of the acting was great, at points he did come across as believable.

This production was a waste of film and an even greater waste of effort to corral the rather large cast onto some desert area.  The sparse description for this movie drops the term "big budget", and if this is actually true it was also a colossal waste of money.  Not much talent was wasted, for there was little to start with among the few actors with speaking lines.

To be fair, I suppose the biblical story was followed somewhat accurately.  The first 84 minutes is devoted to a few Israelites whining about having their tails whipped by threatening Philistines; particularly a very large one named Goliath.  None of the Israelites are willing to face Goliath, who spends 40 days (pretty much all of the first 84 minutes) shouting at them.  Soon one Israelite named David steps forward and tries to explain that his faith in God gives him the strength to challenge and defeat the giant Goliath, but the rest of the crew works very hard to talk him out of it.

Finally around minute 84, despite all the advice to the contrary, David casually walks out to face Goliath and flings a small rock at him.  The rock finds a good landing on Goliath's right eyebrow, stunning the giant into a pre-coma.  This gives David the opportunity to approach Goliath and run him through with his own sword.  Another filmed minute shows all the Israelite nay-sayers cheering David, then the movie goes to credits.

David quoting New Testament passages is bad enough (Without faith it is impossible to please God), with a good script, good directing, good acting, it could be a forgivable offense. But, the fact is, the screenwriter breaks every rule of creative writing, particularly when it comes to show, don't tell. Instead of showing David in a battle with the lion, he simply tells two men to watch out for the lion, because he killed his mate, and she might seek revenge. Most great movies would have shown David in an epic battle arising victoriously after a heated and exhausting battle.

One reviewer here says Goliath is on a loop repeating himself over and over. It's true. He just repeats the same lines over and over. If he has any other lines, I sure don't remember them. I won't debate the size of Goliath here. Whether he was actually 6 to 7 feet tall or 9 to 10 feet is a debate elsewhere. What I will say is, this Goliath is neither terrifying nor is he enough to scare a toddler, much less an entire group of trained warriors.

Speaking of trained warriors. The Israeli army is portrayed as a bunch of untrained, undisciplined, and pathetic wimps hiding from the neighborhood bully. While they were terrified, it wasn't against a pathetic Goliath as portrayed in this movie.

At the end of the day, you will undoubtedly disregard this review and the others, and will watch the movie for the same reason(s) I did. And, like myself, you will have been warned. It really is that bad.

One of the most inspiriting and extraordinary Bible accounts is once again retold in a cinematic manner reminding us it is best expressed from the true literary source. The best production quality of Tim Chey's film version of David and Goliath is the movie poster. Although an ambitious attempt to dramatize the events leading to that ultimate battle of faith the movie spears and stabs itself in every area, each scene possible. The foremost flaws are Chey's direction and writing.
Among the director's weakest results are the inconsistent, often overblown performances ranging from poor to earnest to mediocre, a lot of yelling, threats insults and shouts among the actors. Miles Sloman is a sincere David, grunting, mean faced Jerry Sckolosky is a tall, beer-belly Goliath, Paul Hughes is the anguish overwhelmed King Saul abandoned of God's support. There is also the jealous oldest brother Eliab in Joesph Emms and the soon worrying sick daughter Michal portrayed by a pretty Makenna Guyler. Other actual and fictional Bible characters are thrown in or spoken about to mix up the drama that is frequently cartoonish.
Tim Chey's script include well-known passages and reminders of Bible's events. Like other Biblical retellings it runs off the tracks and goes its' unscriptural path. It was a chief flaw to leave out the colorful, assertive Biblical character Joab, that was Chey's decision. He was replaced by a fictional army chief who's more favorable presence in the film is killed off too soon.
The location shots in Africa seemed authentic. However after you are trying to ignore the amateurish costumes, props, hearing the overplayed music and seeing overdone cloud effects there is the confronting the fact the filmmakers are either professionally careless or uncaring of the significance of David and Goliath's story. It is not impossible to enjoy this movie depending on your mood or attitude. It is a big mistake to begin watching this rushed, pasted together production with high expectations of an faith building experience. David and Goliath is rated PG for sword and choking violence, threats of deaths appearing less troubling than a Saturday morning cartoon.

I'm offended. And let me tell you why. It's not that David, the Shepard Boy turned King is portrayed as a whiny brat that--because he played the harp for someone once--is suddenly given audience with the King to beg his pardon to go get himself killed at every opportunity. Its not that lack of faith in David or God that EVERY OTHER PERSON portrayed in this film shows. Its not the musical score that consists of one song replayed over and over without reason--seeming to get their money's worth out of the rights they paid to use it in the soundtrack. Its not even that the special effects for this "Big Budget" film suck worse than the SF I set up for a Haunted House I did one year on a shoestring budget of $100.

No. I will tell you what really offended me about this film by summing up the first hour and twenty minutes of it in two sentences. "David, you can't do it." and "David, don't try!"

You say this once to give it feeling. You say it twice to press its meaning. But the third, fourth and fortieth time? You're just bludgeoning your audience. The writer couldn't figure out how to show the impossibility of the situation so tried to tell the audience. Over. and over. and over.

But since this is a review, lets touch on some of those other points. David is one of the few true hero stories of the Bible. But he's not portrayed as God's soldier here. He's portrayed as a whiny kid who walks into the middle of a battle and bugs Saul until the king just basically says "Screw it, go get yourself killed!" I did not like David in this movie. I don't blame Saul at ALL for sending that David off to face Goliath.

I'm also not exaggerating about the music score either. You will hate that song by the time the credits roll. And I liked that song. And they killed it for me. Thanks Jerry.

The Special Effects? Here's a tip should anyone from that department read this. Karo syrup and cocoa powder. Pour the syrup in a clear plastic cup and mix in the powder until it is darker than blood. You want it darker if you're putting it on a light surface to make it look realistic. Putting what looked like cherry koolaid on Goliath's face does not make for any realism.

As for the lack of faith? This was someone's unilateral love letter to God, and they wanted to hammer home the concept that faith is stronger than steel. The proof of that was visual. It took 2 seconds...one stone thrown.

There is so much promise in this story that was never even touched upon. You can get all these extras but you can't pay for a harpist to let us hear him play? Why didn't David put on that armor? He didn't even touch the King's sword! But he swung Goliath's rather smartly. We could have had romance with that harp. We could have seen comedy with those oversized weapons. Could have felt urgency with the battles that were never fought, blood that was never shed, and the stomachs that were never fed. That might have explained the lose of faith in the others, to see and hear and experience their suffering during the siege.

Instead of telling those stories, we get "David, you can't do it" and "David, don't try."
